column4: can someone explain to me the two different outputs in this simple commands?
http://paste.ubuntu.com/608007/
whats the problem?
i would expect both lines to yield the same output
I think it may be because of the back ticks in the second command
do you know what the back ticks are supposed to do?
it is executing whats in side them and piping the output to the echo command, I suspect its doing this before receiving the filename from find
doing so before receiving the filename from find is impossible, then it couldnt output anything
Im 99% sure that its not running the 3 commands in the order you think they are
IE first it runs find, then its running basename, and then finally is running echo from the -exec switch and tacking on the filename
thats what i want
no you seem to want, the filename given to basename and then its output piped to echo
the backticks are creating the problem here
whats wrong with the first command? why not just call basename directly?
i want to use -exec diff `basename {}` {}
well, diff has an option to compare directories, if you really need to use find, consider having find create a shell script
om tired of reading man pages over and over again, i thought that was possible to accomplish with just what i know
normally you use diff on a directory, its kinda rare to just use it on one file, and noone ever makes a large set of diff files like that
so diff isnt used to create patches usable with patch cmd?
yes, it is. but you dont patch a file, you patch the entire directory
`diff orig/ new/ > mypatch.diff && cd orig && patch -p1 < ../mypatch.diff`
